snippet: The Obama administration insisted it would not veer from its approach, despite strikes near Damascus by Israel and new questions about the use of chemical arms in Syria’s civil war.
abstract: Obama administration insists it will not be swayed from cautious approach to Syria, despite Israeli military strikes near Damascus and new questions about use of chemical weapons in civil war there; casts doubt on assertion by United Nations official that Syrian rebels, not government of Pres Bashar al-Assad, used nerve agent sarin; backs Israel’s right to strike Syrian targets to disrupt shipments of weapons from Iran to Hezbollah.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Steven Lee Myers contributed reporting from Washington, and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: The Obama administration insisted it would not veer from its approach, despite strikes near Damascus by Israel and new questions about the use of chemical arms in Syria’s civil war.

headline.seo: White House Sticks to Cautious Path on Syria
headline.main: White House Holds Firm on Cautious Path in Syria Crisis
headline.print_headline: White House Sticks to Cautious Path on Syria
